q:
Write a query to print all the columns from the Employee table having location_id as 1810190.

The EMPLOYEE table is described below:

FIELD TYPE
ID NUMBER
NAME VARCHAR(17)
LOCATION_ID NUMBER
DESIGNATION VARCHAR
TIME NUMBER

Options

1.

SELECT * FROM EMPLOYEE WHERE LOCATION_ID = 1810190;

2.

SELECT LOCATION_ID FROM EMPLOYEE WHERE LOCATION_ID=1810190;

3.

SELECT * FROM EMPLOYEE WHERE LOCATION_ID = "1810190";

4.

SELECT ALL FROM EMPLOYEE WHERE LOCATION_ID = 1810190;

Alice is working on Change Data Capture (CDC) to stream the data by using MySQL. If she is required to implement triggers to set up this CDC, then which of the statements in this scenario are correct:

Statements

  1. While implementing CDC, triggers are configured to insert a new row into an external table every time an INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE happens.
  2. Triggers are usually performance-intensive and it can lead to a significant rise in the performance of the transactional database.
  3. Triggers are executed along with the transaction. So if there is anything wrong with the trigger, the entire transaction can fail.

Consider you have Table Employee.

Table: Employee

Eid

  Name Salary Dept
1 Alice 3400 Finance
2 Bob 5600 Marketing
3 Ben 3800 Sales
4 Mike  3200 Marketing
5 Tara 6600 Finance
6 Anita 3000 Marketing
7 Lisa 4800 Production
8 Paul 5000 Production

Stored Procedure

DELIMITER &&  
CREATE PROCEDURE Emp()  
BEGIN  
    SELECT Name,Salary FROM Employee WHERE Dept='Marketing';  
END &&  
DELIMITER ;  

CALL Emp();

 If you are required to execute the above MySQL query , then determine the output?

1.

Name Salary
Bob 5600
Mike 3200
Anita 3000

2.

Name Salary
Bob 5600
Anita 3200
Mike 3000

3.

Name Salary
Bob 5600
Mike 3200
Lisa 3000

4.

Name Salary
Bob 5600
Lisa 4800
Paul 5000

Consider you have Table Employee.

Table: Employee

ID

  Name Birthyear Location
1 Alice 1994 Jaipur
2 Bob 1996 Hyderabad
3 Ben 1997 Delhi
4 Mike  1992 Gurgaon
5 Tara 1998 Pune
6 Anita 1992  Noida
7 Lisa 2000 Pune
8 Paul 2002 Mumbai

Stored Procedure

DELIMITER &&
CREATE PROCEDURE STUD(IN var INT) 
BEGIN  
    SELECT Id FROM Employee WHERE Birthyear>=var ORDER BY Name ;
END &&  
DELIMITER ;  
CALL STUD(1997);

 If you are required to execute the above MySQL query, then determine the output?

ID
3
5
7
8

2.

ID

4

ID

3
5

Consider you have Table Student.

Table: Student

ID

  Name Gender Marks
1 Alice F 7
2 Bob M 8
3 Ben M 5
4 Mike  M 9
5 Tara F 4
6 Anita F 6
7 Lisa F 8

Stored Procedure

DELIMITER &&
CREATE PROCEDURE STUD(IN var1 INT,IN var2 TEXT) 
BEGIN  
    select Id,Name from Student where Gender = var2 AND Marks >= var1  ; 
END &&  
DELIMITER ;  
CALL STUD(6,'M');

 If you are required to execute the above MySQL query, then determine the output?

1.

ID Name
2 Bob
3 Ben

2.

ID Name
2 Bob
3 Ben
4 Mike

3.

ID Name
3 Ben
4 Mike

4.

ID Name
2 Bob
4 Mike

Consider you have Table Employee.

Table: Employee

Eid

  Name Salary Dept Gender
1 Alice 3400 Finance F
2 Bob 5600 Marketing M
3 Ben 3800 Sales M
4 Mike  3200 Marketing M
5 Tara 6600 Finance F
6 Anita 4800 Marketing F
7 Lisa 4800 Production F
8 Paul 5000 Production M

Stored Procedure

DELIMITER &&
CREATE PROCEDURE STUD() 
BEGIN  
    SELECT Name FROM Employee WHERE Salary < (
        SELECT salary FROM Employee WHERE Gender='F' AND Dept = 'Marketing');
END &&  
DELIMITER ;  
CALL STUD();

 If you are required to execute the above MySQL query, then determine the output?

Alice
Ben 
Mike

2.

Name
Bob

Paul

3.

Alice
Bob
Lisa

4.

Bob
Lisa 
Paul

Consider you have Table Employee and Department.

Table: Department

Did Dname Location
1 Finance Delhi
2 Marketing Mumbai
3 Sales Noida
4 Production Delhi
5 Sales Delhi
6 Marketing Mumbai

Table: Employee

Eid

  Name Age
1 Alice 69
2 Bob 74
3 Ben 52
4 Mike  50
5 Tara 78
6 Anita 46
7 Lisa 68
8 Paul 60

Stored Procedure

DELIMITER &&
CREATE PROCEDURE STUD() 
BEGIN  
    SELECT Eid, Name FROM Employee WHERE Age >= 60 AND
    EXISTS (SELECT * FROM Department
       WHERE Location='Delhi' AND
       Department.Did= Employee.Eid);
END &&  
DELIMITER ;  
CALL STUD();

 If you are required to execute the above MySQL query, then determine the output?

1.

Eid Name
1 Alice
4 Mike
5 Tara

2.

Eid Name
1 Alice
4 Mike

3.

Eid Name
1 Alice
4 Mike
7 Lisa

4.

Eid Name
1 Alice
5 Tara

    SELECT ID,Name FROM Student WHERE Gender = 'F' AND Marks >= 6 AND Name LIKE '%a' ;

Vid

2 Bob 18

5 Tara 26
6 Anita 17

Query

SELECT Vid, CASE WHEN age > 17 THEN 'Eligible' WHEN age = 17 THEN 'Eligible next year' ELSE 'Not Eligible' END AS Eligibility FROM Voters;

1.

Vid Eligibility

Query

SELECT Count(*) FROM  ( ( SELECT Name FROM Employee) AS S NATURAL JOIN ( SELECT Salary FROM Employee) AS T );

If you are required to execute the above MySQL query, then determine the output?

Consider you have Table Student.

Table: Student

ID

  Name Gender Marks Grade
1 Alice M 8 A
2 Bob M 9 B
3 Ben M 4 A
4 Mike  M 9 C
5 Tara F 6 D
6 Anita F 7 B
7 Lisa F 5 A

Query

SELECT Name FROM Student WHERE Gender = 'M' GROUP BY Grades HAVING  AVG(Marks) > (SELECT AVG(Marks)FROM Student);

 If you are required to execute the above MySQL query, then determine the output?

1.

Name
Alice
Bob

2.

Name
Alice
Bob
Ben

3.

Alice
Bob
Mike

4.

Bob
Mike

Consider the following relational schemas:
Table: Shops

Variable Attributes
Integer sid
Sting sname
String city
String street

Table: Specifications

Variable Attributes
Integer pid
Sting pname
String color

Table: Items

Variable Attributes
Integer sid
Integer pid
Integer cost

Consider the following relational query on the above database:

​SELECT A.sname FROM Shops A WHERE A.sid NOT IN (SELECT I.sid FROM Items I WHERE I.pid NOT IN (SELECT A.pid FROM Specifications A WHERE A.color<> 'Red'))

If you are required to execute the above MySQL query, Which one of the following is the correct interpretation of the above query?

Interpretations

  1. Find the names of all Shops that have supplied a non-Red Color Specification.
  2. Find the names of all Shops that have not supplied a non-Red Color Specification.
  3. Find the names of all Shops that have supplied only Red Color Specification.
  4. Find the names of all Shops that have not supplied only Red Color Specification.

In SQL Server 2019, you are working with the following object. Which of these conditions returns an empty RowSet:

Object

sys.dm_db_stats_properties

Conditions

  1. The specified object is not found 
  2. Specified statistics ID does not correspond to existing statistics for the specified object ID
  3. The current user does not have permission to view the statistics object

Consider you are given a MySQL query. 

SELECT * FROM (SELECT * FROM table1) AS table2;

Now, if you are given a task to rewrite into a new MySQL query such that it still returns the same output as the old query.

Then, which of the following queries can be used to perform this task?

Statements
1.

SELECT * FROM table1;

 

2.

SELECT * FROM table2;

 

3.

SELECT * FROM table1 AS table2;

In which of the following scenarios is it appropriate to use a SQL Server in an Azure Virtual Machine:

  1. You need control on SQL Server and Windows.
  2. You need full compatibility with SQL Server On-premises and want to move existing applications to Azure.

In MySQL, consider the following join clause. Which of these conditions is null-rejected in this scenario:

SELECT * FROM Table1 LEFT JOIN Table2 ON Table1.A=Table2.A
  1. Table2.A IS NULL
  2. Table2.A IS NOT NULL
  3. Table2.A > 3

Consider you are given the MySQL query

Query :

SELECT * FROM Table1 LEFT JOIN Table2 ON Table2.A=Table1.A
                 LEFT JOIN Table3 ON Table3.B=Table1.B
  WHERE Table3.B > 0

Considering the above MySQL query, which of the following statements about the null-rejection condition is correct.

Statements

  1. There cannot be any null rejections.
  2. The null-rejection condition can occur for the first outer join operation but not for the second one.
  3. The null-rejection condition can occur for the second outer join operation but not for the first one.
  4. The null-rejection condition can occur for both operations.

Value
1
2
2

3 4
4 5

2.

Value Rank

2 2
2 3
3 4
4 5

3.

In MS SQL, you have created Red Hat Enterprise Linux virtual machines (VMs) in an availability set of your resource group. If you are required to enable High Availability features to your VM nodes, then which of the following Azure CLI commands is used to open the host files and set the resolution of the host name?

In MS SQL, you have created Red Hat Enterprise Linux virtual machines (VMs) in an availability set of your resource group. You are testing the connection between the created VMs. Which of the following Azure CLI commands in Azure Cloud Shell is used to connect a VM to another VM in this scenario?

In MS SQL, you are migrating SQL Server to Azure SQL Database Offline by using Data Migration Service. If you are assessing the source SQL Server’s database that is migrating to a pooled database in Azure SQL Database, then which of the following assessment report types is selected by default in this scenario:
    1. Check database compatibility
    2. Check feature parity

In MySQL, consider a table empname_tbl with an attribute emp_name. You want to determine the number of employees whose name starts with a vowel and ends with 'ok'. Which of the following queries can be used to perform this task?

a.option: SELECT emp_name FROM empname_tbl WHERE emp_name REGEXP '^aeiou$ok';
SELECT emp_name FROM empname_tbl WHERE emp_name REGEXP '^[αeiou]|ok$';
SELECT emp_name FROM empname_tbl WHERE emp_name REGEXP '[^aeiou]$ok';
SELECT emp_name FROM empname_tbl WHERE emp_name REGEXP '[^aeiou$ok'];

q:
Consider the following definition of the table Student.

SID name age marks
2 Alice 23 89
4 Bob 24 85
6 John 22 80
1 Tara 28 99
3 Mike 25 90

Now consider the 2 MySQL queries.
Query 1 :

SELECT * FROM Student WHERE name='Bob' AND age=24

Query 2 :

SELECT * FROM Student WHERE marks=85

Which of the above MySQL queries returns a constant table?

Consider the product table.

Table : product

p_code p_name Price
1 Paul 10.15
2 John 15.99
3 Mary 15.50
4 Lisa 25.25
5 Anita 30.33
6 Tara 15.55

Which of these SQL queries must be used to round off the price to one decimal place in the above product table:

1.

SELECT p_code, price, ROUND (price, 1) FROM product;

2.

SELECT p_code, price, TRUNCATE(price, 1) FROM product;

3.

SELECT p_code, price, ABS(price, 1) FROM product;

In MS SQL, you are migrating SQL Server to Azure SQL Database Offline by using Data Migration Service. If you are running multiple named SQL Server instances by using dynamic ports, then which of the following ports must be granted access to the key through the firewall in this scenario?

You are now working on SQL commands. Below are the details of tables Students and Results.

Table : Students

id name
1 Alice
2 Bob
3 Ben
4 Mike

Table : Results

id marks
2 9
4 8
5 10

Below is a MySQL query that is implemented using joins.

Query : 

SELECT Students.id, Results.marks FROM Students INNER JOIN Results ON Students.id=Results.id;

Which of the following options is the output of the above MySQL Query?

1.

id marks
1 NULL
2 9
3 NULL
4 8

2.

id marks
2 9
4 8
5 NULL

3.

id marks
2 9
4 8

4.

id marks

In MySQL, which of the following sequences represents the correct sequence of execution of the clauses given below in a SELECT statement:

  • GROUP BY
  • WHERE
  • HAVING

Consider the following table pets, where it represents the pet_id and size of each pet.

Table : pets

pet_id size
1 3
2 1
3 7
4 1
5 4
6 7
7 7

Using the above table, if you are required to write a MySQL query that should return each pet size and the number of pets with that corresponding pet size, then which of the following query will give the correct output.

1.

SELECT m.size, COUNT(SELECT size FROM pets where size=m.size) FROM pets GROUP BY size;

2.

SELECT size, COUNT(*) FROM pets GROUP BY COUNT(*)

3.

SELECT size, COUNT(*) FROM pets GROUP BY size;

4.

SELECT m.size, COUNT(SELECT size FROM pets where size=m.size) FROM pets GROUP BY m.size;

In MySQL, consider the following table called Employee.

Table: Employee

EMPID NAME SALARY DEPARTMENT MANAGER
101 John 10000 PCP NULL
102 Paul 45000 LLM NULL
103 Mary 26500 LLM 102
104 Anita 40000 LLM 102
105 Mike 52600 PCP 101

You want to display the IDs (EMPID) and names(NAME) of the employees other than 'Anita' who are working in the same department as 'Anita'.

Which of the following MySQL queries returns the correct output for the above task?

1.

SELECT E1.EMPID, E1.NAME FROM Employee E1 INNER JOIN Employee E2 ON E1.DEPARTMENT = E2.DEPARTMENT AND E1.EMPID <> E2.EMPID AND E2.NAME='Hetmayer';

 

2.

SELECT E1.EMPID, E1.NAME FROM Employee E1 INNER JOIN Employee E2 ON E1.DEPARTMENT = E2.DEPARTMENT AND E1.EMPID = E2.EMPID AND E2.NAME='Hetmayer';

 

3.

SELECT E1.EMPID, E1.NAME FROM Employee E1 INNER JOIN Employee E2 ON E1.DEPARTMENT = E2.DEPARTMENT AND E1.EMPID = E2.EMPID AND E2.NAME<>'Hetmayer';

 

4.

SELECT E1.EMPID, E1.NAME FROM Employee E1 OUTERJOIN Employee E2 ON E1.DEPARTMENT = E2.DEPARTMENT AND E1.EMPID <> E2.EMPID AND E2.NAME='Hetmayer';

Consider the following MySQL table named employees.

Table: employees

Attribute Data type
employee_id INTEGER
department_id INTEGER

If you want to perform a task to list the departments with department_id and the number of employees in each department such there should be more than 3 employees in each department.

Then which of the following MySQL queries will give the correct output for the above task?

1.

SELECT COUNT(employee_id),department_id FROM employees GROUP BY department_id;

2.

SELECT COUNT(employee_id),department_id FROM employees GROUP BY department_id HAVING COUNT(employee_id)>3;

3.

SELECT COUNT(employee_id),department_id FROM employees GROUP BY employee_id HAVING COUNT(*)>3;

4.

SELECT COUNT(employee_id),department_id FROM employees GROUP BY employee_id HAVING COUNT(employee_id)>3;

In MySQL, consider the following table Student.

Table: Student

Attribute Data type
Roll no INTEGER
Name VARCHAR2(10)
Gender CHAR(1)
DOJ DATE

You are performing operations on the above table. Then, which of the following insert operations can cause an error?

1.

INSERT INTO Student VALUES(1, 'Root', 'Male', '20-JAN-15');

2.

INSERT INTO Student VALUES(1, 'Root', 'M', '20-JAN-15');

3.

INSERT INTO Student VALUES(1, 'Root', 'M', '2015-JAN-@0');

4.

INSERT INTO Student VALUES(1, 'Root', 'M', NULL);

Consider you have tables Students and Results. 

Table : Students

id name
2 Bob
4 Mike
1 Alice
3 Ben

Table : Results

id marks
4 9
2 10
5 8
1 7
6 6

Below you are given a MySQL query that does not include joins.

Query :

SELECT SUM(Results.marks) FROM Students, Results WHERE Students.id=Results.id;

Now if you implement the above MySQL query with joins then which of the following options will give the same output as the above query?

1.

SELECT SUM(Results.marks) FROM Students INNER JOIN Results;

2.

SELECT SUM(Results.marks) FROM Students INNER JOIN Results ON Students.id=Results.id;

3.

SELECT SUM(Results.marks) FROM Students RIGHT JOIN Results ON Students.id=Results.id;

4.

SELECT SUM(Results.marks) FROM Students RIGHT JOIN Results;

Consider you have tables Students and Results. 

Table: Students

id name
2 Bob
4 Mike
1 Alice
3 Ben

Table : Results

id marks
4 9
2 10
5 8
1 9
6 10

Below you are given a MySQL query that returns the number of students and their marks from the tables Students and Results who score the same marks for every mark value.

SELECT count(Students.id), Results.marks FROM Students INNER JOIN Results ON Students.id=Results.id GROUP BY Results.marks;

Now if you implement the above MySQL query without using joins then which of the following queries will give the same output as the above query?

1.

SELECT count(Students.id), Results.marks FROM Students, Results WHERE Students.id=Results.id GROUP BY Results.marks;

2.

SELECT count(Students.id), Results.marks FROM Students, Results WHERE Students.id=Results.id;

3.

SELECT count(Students.id), Results.marks FROM Students, Results GROUP BY Results.marks;

4.

SELECT count(Students.id), Results.marks FROM Students, Results GROUP BY Results.marks WHERE Students.id=Results.id;

In MS SQL, if you are creating an Azure resource group by using the Azure command-line interface (Azure CLI), then which of the following statements about the Azure CLI commands are correct:

Statements
    1. The az subscription set command is used to set a subscription to a currently active subscription.
    2. The az group create command is used to create a resource group.
    3. The az SQL DB create command is used to create a database for the resource group.

Consider the following table named Employee.

Table: Employee

EmpNo Name Department
1 Tara WWR
2 Anita IVVT
3 Lisa DEV
4 Mary DEV

From the above table, if you are asked to display all the departments that have more than one employee using MySQL. 

Then, which of the following queries can be used to perform the above task?

1.

SELECT Department, COUNT(*) FROM Employee GROUP BY Department WHERE COUNT(*) > 1

2.

SELECT Department, COUNT(*) FROM Employee GROUP BY Department, COUNT(*) HAVING COUNT(*)>1

3.

SELECT Department, COUNT(*) FROM Employee GROUP BY Department HAVING COUNT(*) > 1

4.

SELECT Department, COUNT(*) FROM Employee GROUP BY COUNT(*) HAVING COUNT(Department) > 1

In MySQL, consider a table named Product consisting of prodId, prodName, price, category, discount. You asked to display the prodId and prodName of the products that belong to either 'Sports' or 'Clothes' category and display in the ascending order of prices and descending order of discounts. Then, which of the following queries will give the correct output. 

1.

Select prodId, prodName from Product where category in('Sports','Clothes') order by price ascending, discount

2.

Select prodId, prodName from Product where category in('Sports','Clothes') order by price asc, discount

3.

Select prodId, prodName from Product where category in('Sports','Clothes') order by price, discount desc

4.

Select prodId, prodName from Product where category in('Sports','Clothes') order by price, discount

Consider you have tables Students and Results.

id name

Query :

SELECT count(Students.id), Results.marks FROM Students INNER JOIN Results ON Students.id=Results.id GROUP BY Results.marks;

1.

count(id) marks

1 10

 

2.

count(id) marks

2 9

 

3.

count(id) marks

SELECT Students.id, Results.marks FROM Students LEFT JOIN Results ON Students.id=Results.id where Results.marks>8;

id marks

id marks

Consider the following Product table.

Table : Product

p_code p_name p_descr
1 Alice A nail is a pin-shaped object of metal
2 Bob A washer is a thin plate with a hole
3 Ben A nut is faster with a threaded hole
4 Mike A screw or bolt is a type of fastener
5 Tara The most expensive nut in the market
6 Anita The newer nut introduced in May 2013

If you asked to search for rows that contain the string 'nut' in their column 'p_descr'. Then, which of the following queries can be used to perform this task?

1.

SELECT * FROM product WHERE p_descr LIKE '%nut%';

2.

SELECT * FROM product WHERE p_descr LIKE 'nut';

3.

SELECT * FROM product WHERE p_descr ="nut";

4.

SELECT * FROM product WHERE p_descr LIKE 'nut*';

In MS SQL, you are migrating SQL Server to Azure SQL Database Offline by using Data Migration Service. If you have disabled your Windows firewall to allow Azure Database Migration Service to access the source SQL server, then determine the default TCP port number in this scenario?

In MS SQL, you are working on the security features for your SQL Database. You have created a new key in Key Vault.     1. VaultName
    2. InputFile
    3. KeyID

Consider the table table1.

Table : table1

Attribute Data type
a1 INTEGER
a2 INTEGER
a3 INTEGER
var INTEGER


MySQL Query :

SELECT DISTINCT a1, a2, a3 FROM table1
WHERE a1 > var;

 Which of the following MySQL queries represent the above query:

1.

SELECT DISTINCT a1, a2, a3 FROM table1 WHERE a1 > var GROUP BY a1

2.

SELECT a1, a2, a3 FROM table1 WHERE a1 > var GROUP BY a1

3.

SELECT a1, a2, a3 FROM table1 WHERE a1 > var GROUP BY a1, a2, a3;

In MySQL, consider the provided tables. You want to list the following information about the employees. Which of these queries can be used to list these requirements?

Employee information

  • Username
  • The first name
  • The last name
  • Employees working in the Operations department

Table: EmployeeTbl

EMP_ID User_name F_Name L_name Dep_ID
1 AAlice Alice Smith 1
2 BBob Bob Jones 2
3 BBen Ben Johnson 2
4 MMike Mike White 2
5 AAnita Anita Williams 3
6 LLisa Lisa Davis 3
7 MMary Mary Brown 4
8 JJohn John Wilson 4

Table: DepertmentsTbl

Dep_ID Dep_name
1 Technical Innovations
2 Technical Support
3 Operations
4 Customer Delight

a.option:
select e1.User_name,e1.F_Name,e1.L_Name,e2.Dep_name 
from EmployeeTbl e1 inner join DepartmentsTbl e2 
on e1.Dep_ID=e2.Dep_ID
where e2.Dep_name ="Operations"

select User_name,F_Name,L_Name,Dep_name 
from EmployeeTbl e1 inner join DepartmentsTbl e2 
on e1.Dep_ID=e2.Dep_ID
where Dep_name ="Operations"

select e1.User_name,e1.F_Name,e1.L_Name,e2.Dep_name 
from EmployeeTbl e1 inner join DepartmentsTbl e2 
on e1.Dep_ID=e2.Dep_ID

select e1.User_name,e1.F_Name,e1.L_Name,e2.Dep_name 
from EmployeeTbl e1 inner join DepartmentsTbl e2 
where e2.Dep_name ="Operations"
